content: The "Small Business Jobs Amendments Act of 2010" may be cited as such. Amendments are made to the Small Business Lending Fund. Amendments to the Small Business Jobs Act of 2010 include changes to section 4102 regarding small business lending companies with total assets equal to or less than a certain amount. Amendments to the Small Business Jobs Act of 2010 include changes to section 4102 for small business lending companies with total assets of $10,000,000,000 or less. The term 'small business' and 'small business lending company' are defined in accordance with the Small Business Act. Amendments to the Small Business Jobs Act of 2010 include changes to section 4103 for small business lending companies. Debt instruments issued by eligible institutions organized in mutual form or under subchapter S of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 will be included in tier 1 capital. The Secretary, in consultation with the Community Development Financial Institutions Fund, will develop eligibility criteria for CDLFs to participate in the Program and repay the investment. Criteria may include net asset ratio, loan loss reserves ratio, positive net income, operating liquidity ratio, and delinquent loans ratio. The Program requires CDLFs to meet eligibility criteria such as equity, loan loss reserves, audited financial statements, clean audit opinion, and three years of operating experience. Amendments include increasing the percentage in paragraph (1)(F) to 10 percent and adding incentives for increasing the number of loans made within the first 4.5 years after receiving a capital investment. The Program incentivizes eligible institutions to increase small business lending by adjusting the rate of dividends and interest on preferred stock issued to the Treasury based on lending performance. The Program incentivizes eligible institutions to increase small business lending by adjusting the rate of dividends and interest on preferred stock issued to the Treasury based on lending performance. An eligible institution may choose to compute their small business lending amount by certifying that all lending included for the increase in lending was made to small businesses. The Program incentivizes eligible institutions to increase small business lending by adjusting the rate of dividends and interest on preferred stock issued to the Treasury based on lending performance. In paragraph (8), amendments are made to outreach efforts to minorities, women, veterans, and Indian tribes, including representation or collaboration with Indian Tribes. The Program requires eligible institutions to disclose loan information and reports on their website, emphasizing non-discrimination in lending practices. The Equal Credit Opportunity Act requires non-discrimination in lending practices based on race, color, religion, national origin, sex, marital status, or age. Additionally, there are provisions to increase credit availability for small businesses operating on Tribal trust lands or other Indian areas. SEC. 4113. TEMPORARY AMORTIZATION AUTHORITY. The purpose of this section is to address the ongoing effects of the financial crisis on small businesses by providing temporary authority to amortize losses or write-downs in order to increase credit availability. Eligible institutions can choose to amortize losses on a quarterly basis for real estate owned or impaired loans secured by real estate, following specific guidelines. During the initial 2-year period, eligible institutions can adjust their amortization period based on the change in small business lending. If lending increases by less than 2.5 percent, the period is 6 years. If it increases by 2.5 percent or more but less than 5.0 percent, the period is adjusted accordingly. During the initial 2-year period, eligible institutions can adjust their amortization period based on the change in small business lending. If lending increases by 5.0 percent or greater, the amortization period shall be 8 years. If it increases by 7.5 percent or greater, the period shall be 9 years. If it increases by 10 percent or greater, the period shall be 10 years. Minimum underwriting standards must be followed by eligible institutions choosing to amortize any loss or write-down. The Small Business Jobs Act of 2010 requires eligible institutions to follow minimum underwriting standards for loans made between January 1, 2003, and January 1, 2008. Additionally, a technical amendment was made to the table of contents. SEC. 3. EFFECTIVE DATE. This Act and its amendments will take effect on the later of the enactment of this Act or the Small Business Jobs Act of 2010.
